cards.title: Our favourite things this week / From surfing in crisis to baseball poetry via Maradona
cards.rawTitle: From surfing in crisis to baseball poetry via Maradona

item.title: Our favourite things online this week: from baseball poetry to Diego Maradona
item.trailText: Featuring Rebecca Adlington on dedication, Paul Gascoigne on life after football, Stephen Hunt on Cristiano Ronaldo and Ronnie O’Sullivan on Haile Gebrselassie
item.standFirst: Featuring Rebecca Adlington on dedication, Paul Gascoigne on life after football, Stephen Hunt on Cristiano Ronaldo and Ronnie O’Sullivan on Haile Gebrselassie
item.body:
1) The girl who escaped the Taliban and became a footballer

Nadia Nadim has an unlikely story. She grew up in Afghanistan, where the Taliban took control in 1996 and banned women from working, leaving their house without male supervision and playing sports. She is now a professional footballer who represents Denmark and earns her living at Sky Blue FC in the National Women’s Soccer League. Leander Schaerlaeckens tells her story in Vice Sports.

2) Can anyone save the surfing industry?

Ignacio Chavarria is probably the first Ecuador-based investment and project analyst to feature on these pages but his very particular set of skills make him an intriguing writer. In recent posts he has monitored the Google search traffic devoted to football transfer rumours and calculated whether Borat is more readable than Socrates, but his ability to decipher and understand data is probably best used in this article about the declining interest in surfing. Surfing feels like one of those sports that sits on the periphery of the mainstream without ever becoming more or less popular. Apparently that’s not the case at all. Surfing is in crisis.

3) Once upon a time in Mexico

Diego Maradona’s second goal against England at the 1986 World Cup has been described in many ways over the past three decades. Barry Davies probably put it best at the time with his “Oh, you have to say, that is magnificent” line, with Jimmy Magee’s “a goal of the gods” commentary on RTÉ also capturing the imagination of viewers. It feel as if the shimmying run and finish has been remembered, reassessed and rejoiced over since it hit Peter Shilton’s net, but film writer Trinankur Banerjee has managed to cast Fifa’s very own Goal of the Century in a new light in this piece for the Goalden Times website. He thinks the Maradona’s goal is best interpreted as a John Ford western.

4) Rebecca Adlington on Desert Island Discs

If you want to know what it takes to become an Olympic champion, listen to this Desert Island Discs podcast with Rebecca Adlington.

5) CF Monterrey have a stadium 69 years after their formation

And isn’t the view spectacular:

6) Bartolo Colon has never stolen a base

That headline might not mean much to you but Tom Keiser’s article in The Classical – written in the form of a poem – explains the details.

7) Stephen Hunt on the Irishman Abroad

Stephen Hunt is no stranger to this page. In the last six months, two of his Irish Independent columns have featured on here – the first was about his struggles at Euro 2012 and the second touched on his relationship with José Mourinho. He has continued his run of fine journalism with this appearance on The Irishman Abroad podcast.

Hunt is a terrific talker. He chats here about Giovanni Trapattoni being a “genius”, Cristiano Ronaldo being “obviously” the best player he has faced and how he opened a gastropub to stave off the boredom that comes with being professional athlete. Hunt will be a great pundit – if he doesn’t go into management.

8) What makes a sport a sport?

Jon Hotten, the man behind The Old Batsman cricket website, has started a new blog to house his other sportswriting. It’s called The Old Batsman on Sport. Thankfully his writing is more imaginative than the name of his new website. Jon is one of the most fluent storytellers working today – and you don’t even have to buy a newspaper to read his stuff. This recent piece – entitled “Ronnie O’Sullivan and normal shoes” – shows off his easy, winning style.

9) How Maria Sharapova became the world’s wealthiest female athlete

If you take a trip to Wimbledon this summer you will probably stumble upon Sugarpova, the local pop-up sweet shop that belongs to Maria Sharapova – see what she did there? – in the village. The place is a rip-off but it’s hard to walk past it without delving inside for a nosey. The sweets are preposterously overpriced but Sharapova must be doing something right. She’s worth $110m and I’m baulking at the price of confectionery. As Ashlee Vance notes in this piece for Bloomberg, Sharapova cannot match Serena Williams on the court, but she blows her away off it:

Williams continues to break records. With 19 career Grand Slam titles, she’s tied for the third most of all time. She’s recently had the second-longest winning streak of her career, with 27 in a row. If she keeps it up, Williams could snag every major title this season. Second place has its consolations, though, especially if you are tall and blonde. Sharapova is the highest-paid female athlete in the world, according to Forbes, and she’s topped the list for the past decade. She made $22m from endorsements in 2014, including an eight-year, $70m deal with Nike, a five-year contract with Evian, and deals with Cole Haan, Tag Heuer, and other brands. Williams, who also has a deal with Nike, as well as one with Gatorade, lags behind by more than $10m each year.

10) Paul Gascoigne on the Stephen Nolan show

Paul Gascoigne has been doing the rounds recently to promote a new documentary about his life. He joined us in the Guardian for an hour to talk about Bryan “dog poo” Robson, Ally “Coisty” McCoist and the day he dressed up in a Santa costume to entertain Sepp Blatter. Most of Gascoigne’s recent interviews covered the familiar football stories – the early promise at Tottenham, his tears at Italia 90, the Lazio adventure and his goal against Scotland at Euro 96 – but Stephen Nolan delved into more personal topics on his BBC Radio Ulster show.

cards.title: The Fiver / Sign up to our free, funny email. OK, our free email

item.title: Tough is her middle name
item.trailText: In today’s Fiver: The Lionesses, ‘Arry Redknapp and Algerian TV ‘merking’
item.standFirst: Click here to have the Fiver sent to your inbox every weekday at 5pm, or if your usual copy has stopped arriving
item.body:
BRONZE STANDARD

The front page of Tuesday morning’s Swedish sports daily Sportbladet said it all. Above a picture of a grieving, defeated Norwegian were the words: “Finally, some good news.” (The words were in Swedish, obviously.) They weren’t simply revelling in their neighbours’ misfortune – delicious as that kind of celebration can be – but delighting in their own Olympic qualifying boost. For, had England lost, Sweden’s women would have had no chance at all of being in Rio. Now they could make that journey after all, just as long as Japan beat Holland and the Swedes then win a play-off competition later this year also involving the Dutch, the Norwegians and Switzerland. In other words they still probably won’t go to Rio, but England’s victory at least gave them a kind of giant national straw, which they are now clutching with such gleeful desperation it’s as if they’re used to anything decent coming flat, boxed, and requiring eight and a half hours of frustrating self-assembly.

Despite their excitement and profound gratitude Sportbladet were composed enough to seek exclusive reaction from England’s match-winner, Lucy Bronze. (And isn’t it strange, incidentally, that British phonebooks are dripping in Golds, have long chains of Silvers and are occasionally stabbed by a Steel, but after that nobody has any other metal names except Freddie Mercury, Lucy Bronze and Tintin. And two of those names are made up.) Asked how she felt about the hope she had given to the entire nation of Sweden, Bronze enthused: “Oops, I didn’t know.”

Things looked bad for England as they laboured through a disappointing first half, which somehow ended goalless and, when Solveig Gulbrandsen headed Norway into the lead from a 54th-minute corner, Mark Sampson’s side looked not so much Lionesses as Lioness-oh-esses. Fortunately, captain Steph Houghton answered the mayday, and with 14 minutes to go Bronze completed the comeback with a brilliant 20-yard top-corner-bound thundercracker.

It was a tough chance, but then tough is her middle name (it actually is), and Bronze celebrated with an unusually lengthy choreographed fist-bump routine – also involving unused substitute Jordan Nobbs – of such extravagance that, had it only been done by two men at the men’s World Cup, it would have absolutely guaranteed a lucrative advertising deal for a large pizza chain and a post-retirement invite to Strictly Come Dancing.

Onwards, then, to the quarter-finals, where England face Canada on Saturday night. As for Norway, it’s the long trip home. As it happens, it’s the birthday of their striker Isabell Herlovsen, who won her 104th cap in Monday’s defeat. “I told the girls I’d be spending my birthday on a plane to Vancouver, not on the way back to Norway,” she sobbed afterwards. “Now it’s going to be a crappy day.” But hang on a minute, Norway – just like Sweden – have been guaranteed a spot in that possible Olympic play-off thanks to England win. And one of them gives us gleeful front-page expressions of eternal gratitude, while the other heaves up foul-mouthed misery. Honestly, there’s no pleasing some people.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

“It’s not bad, it’s actually quite fine. I had some work done on it and I feel a lot better. But this is a bit different for me compared to previous years – I’m not stressed out. Normally you’re getting ready for pre-season, looking to get one or two in and preparing a trip away. Until the season starts up, you don’t know how much you’ll miss it. I missed it a bit when I left but I needed a break. I was struggling. I spent most of the time at training sitting down and that wasn’t enjoyable. I want to be hands on. It was frustrating, it drove me mad. But the break has done me good – I needed it” – here comes ‘Arry.

FIVER LETTERS

“Surely Partick Thistle’s mascot (yesterday’s Bits and Bobs) should be a thistle called Patrick? Am off to sleep with the lights on. For the rest of my life” – Dan Davies.

“My favourite day of the year is when the draws for the opening round of Big Vase come out. Quite a thrill to read all the tiny, obscure teams that have a chance for greatness, like Cukaricki Belgrade, Rabotnicki Kometal, Jagiellonia Bialystok and West Ham. But my favourite this year is Sheriff v Odd. I think I saw that movie a few years ago, one of those comic-book things Hollywood puts out for the summer. Right?” – Jerry Slaff.

“A and B are two players who played for club X together after 2000. A went on to play for club Y in another league and even won the league title there. B later on went to play for club Z (league rival of Y) and he too won the league title there. Soon afterwards, A and B were reunited at club W for two seasons after which A left club W. Before retiring, A returned to play for club X again. Interestingly, both A and B have won just one Big Cup for different clubs. Guess A, B, X, Y, Z, W” – Samson Bankole.

• Send your letters to the.boss@theguardian.com. And if you’ve nothing better to do you can also tweet the Fiver. Today’s winner of our prizeless letter o’the day is: Jerry Slaff.

JOIN GUARDIAN SOULMATES

Chances are that if you’re reading this tea-timely football email, you’re almost certainly single. But fear not – if you’d like to find companionship or love, sign up here to view profiles of the kind of erudite, sociable and friendly folk who would never normally dream of going out with you. And don’t forget, it’s not the rejection that kills you, it’s the hope.

BITS AND BOBS

José Mourinho has reluctantly accepted he may have to unchain Petr Cech from the Chelsea dressing room radiator and let him go to Arsenal if the goalkeeper is to salvage something from his teetering career.

Seven people have been nabbed by Italian fuzz over suspected match-fixing involving Catania in Serie B.

Norwich have nipped in to sign 2012’s Youssouf Mulumbu on a free transfer after West Brom happily let the midfielder’s contract expire. “He has vast experience. You generally say a player comes into their peak between 27 and 32, and he is right in the middle of that,” honked manager Alex Neil.

Japanese football officials have denied claims they paid $1.5m to South American football suits in return for support for its co-hosting of the 2002 World Cup. “It’s impossible,” sniffed JFA hononary president Junji Ogura. “Besides, we don’t have such a sum of money.”

Russia don’t either, it seems, and have cut the 2018 World Cup budget by £340m. “We’re primarily taking out the excess hotels,” parped sports minister Vitaly Mutko, in worrying news for Fifa officials who enjoy a bit of excess. And if there’s one thing they like …

And Rivaldo, 78, is considering bringing his bandy legs out of retirement at Brazilian Serie B club Mogi Mirim. “If my knee is OK, maybe I can help in a few games,” he yelled.

STILL WANT MORE?

This week’s edition of The Gallery isn’t too bad, as Jack Grealish stars as Morrissey, a beanstalk-climber and most of the cast of Peaky Blinders.

Parma, the football club milked for all their worth. A terrific long read from David Gendelman, courtesy of the nice people at Howler magazine.

Dare you enter the terrifying world of football mascots? Oh, you do.

Sid Lowe explains how the mucky stuff hit the fan between Sergio Ramos and Real Madrid.

USA! USA!! USA!!! winger Julian Green lets off some steam in this chat with Jack Kerr.

Andrea Pirlo is a dubious luxury for NYC FC unless they think long-term, reckons Graham Parker.

Goals of the week, goals of the week, goals of the week. Goals of the week.

Oh, and if it’s your thing … you can follow Big Website on Big Social FaceSpace.

RECOMMENDED LISTENING

The latest in our Football Weekly presents … series of documentaries focuses on The Gambler: the story of Jimmy Nielsen.

SIGN UP TO THE FIVER

Want your very own copy of our free tea-timely(ish) email sent direct to your inbox? Has your regular copy stopped arriving? Click here to sign up.

AND YOU THOUGHT RIO’S ‘MERKS’ WERE DODGY

cards.title: The Rumour Mill / Austin to Newcastle? Cillesen to Man Utd?
cards.rawTitle: Austin to Newcastle? Cillesen to Man Utd?

item.title: Football transfer rumours: Charlie Austin to Newcastle United?
item.trailText: Jasper Cillesen to Manchester United? | Javier Hernández to Atlético Madrid? | Nani to Fenerbahce? | Roberto Soldado to Galatasaray?
item.standFirst: Today’s tittle-tattle is hoping for a biscuit or a shiny sticker album
item.body:
Suspicions are growing that Manchester United are dragging out negotiations over David de Gea until such time as the Euro implodes and Real Madrid have no usable notes with which to pay for the goalkeeper. That will mean the whole epic saga will have to be aborted and the young Spaniard will be forced to remain at United. Unless, that is, Real find some other token of exchange – and this is where the Daily Mail starts to get excited. “Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale, Karim Benzema, Luka Modric, Raphael Varane and Dani Carvajal could all come up in negotiations with United,” blurts the giddy organ before adding a disclaimer for the benefit of the light of head: “there are no guarantees that United will get their way.”

Related: Petr Cech closes in on Arsenal move after Chelsea reluctantly pave way

Meanwhile the Daily Mirror reckons that if De Gea eventually move to Real, Louis Van Gaal will replace him with Ajax goalkeeper Jasper Cillessen. You may remember Cillessen as the keeper whom Van Gaal humiliated in the World Cup by hauling him off just before a penalty shootout and replacing him with Tim Krul, all of which raises an interesting issue: if Cillessen joins, what will happen when United concede a penalty at Old Trafford? Ah, yes, silly question.

Elsewhere, Manchester City’s interest in Fabian Delph appears to have cooled, but the club continues to have the hots for Jack Wilshere and, if they fail to land Paul Pogba, will submit an offer for the midfielder that Arsène Wenger cannot refuse. Hmm, something about that last sentence doesn’t feel quite right. Reckon it’s that bit about Arsène Wenger, Earth’s most stubborn man, not being able to refuse an offer. Never underestimate Wenger’s powers of refusal. If the man were not a football manager, he would be a record-breaking fakir, capable of lying on beds of nails for years while refusing to acknowledge any pain. Having said that, Wenger’s concentration may be weak at the moment, as word is he’s deliberating over what to do now that Geoffrey Kondogbia has left Monaco for Inter rather than London. Having failed to take the player from Monaco, perhaps Wenger will take inspiration from them? For the Ligue 1 club are planning to re-invest some of the Kondogbia windfall in William Carvalho. Milan, who had been even more interested in Kondogbia than Arsenal were, are also eyeing up Carvalho, but may plump for Marseille’s Giannelli Imbula or Zenit’s Axel Witsel instead. Lots of names for you there, Arsène.

No excuses. Juventus want to prise Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from Monaco, and there is not much Liverpool can do about that no matter what they think. Meanwhile, New York City are to offer Andrea Pirlo a holiday in the USA.

Newcastle hope that offering Charlie Austin the No9 shirt could be the key incentive that will make the striker choose to go to St James’ Park. And if that doesn’t work, maybe the club will throw in a biscuit or a shiny sticker album, too.

Tottenham hope that holding the door open for Roberto Soldado and handing him his suitcases will help convince the former striker to leave White Hart Lane for Galatasaray. Also Turkey-bound, if Manchester United’s wishes come true, is Nani, in whom Fenerbahce are interested.

Javier Hernández, meanwhile, is on his way back to Madrid, not to Real but to Atlético. Sevilla want Steven Nzonzi and are prepared to help Stoke keep up the ‘z’ quotient on their team-sheet by giving them the Polish midfielder Grzegorz Krychowiak in return.

And Sunderland are chasing Stewart Downing, whom they fear may be tempted to rejoin Middlesbrough instead.

headerImage.caption: Is Charlie Austin set to sneak off to Tyneside? Photograph: Alan Walter/Action Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Is Charlie Austin set to sneak off to Tyneside?

item.title: Jack Grealish | The Gallery
item.trailText: The Aston Villa midfielder stars as Morrissey, the star of Jack and the Beanstalk and a member of the Peaky Blinders cast
item.standFirst: This week’s winner is Shane Cahill, who gets a copy of Ben Smith’s Journeyman: One man’s odyssey through the lower leagues of English football. Get in touch to claim your prize. Next week we’d like your takes on Bastian Schweinsteiger. Send your efforts to gallery@theguardian.com by noon on Monday 29 June as a jpeg, complete with a caption. Anyone who forgets will be summoned to Guardian Towers for a stern talking to

cards.title: Football Weekly presents … / The Gambler: the Jimmy Nielsen story
cards.rawTitle: The Gambler: the Jimmy Nielsen story

item.title: Football Weekly presents … The Gambler: the Jimmy Nielsen story
item.trailText: Jimmy Nielsen was once dubbed the new Peter Schmeichel, but it was gambling rather than goalkeeping that dominated his early career. This is the story of how a Millwall benchwarmer became an MLS icon
item.standFirst: Jimmy Nielsen was once dubbed the new Peter Schmeichel, but it was gambling rather than goalkeeping that dominated his early career. This is the story of how a Millwall benchwarmer became an MLS icon
item.byline: Presented by Iain Macintosh, produced by Matthew Nelson, edited by Ben Green
item.body:
In the second of our Football Weekly presents … documentaries, we bring you the story of Jimmy Nielsen, a goalkeeper who had it all, nearly lost everything, and finally hit the jackpot.

Iain Macintosh, editor of The Set Pieces, tells us how the man once dubbed the new Peter Schmeichel – and not just because they shared the same hairstyle and physique – battled his addictions to achieve cult hero status with a late-career hurrah in MLS.

You can read more about Jimmy here, and please give us your feedback on the blog below. There's another goalkeeping tale next week, and if you missed our episode about Robin Friday, head here.

Football Weekly presents … is a collaboration between the Guardian and Howler Radio, the audio offshoot of football quarterly Howler Magazine. It was written and produced in its original form by Matthew Nelson. This reworked version is brought to you Matthew and Producer Ben.
